questions.text: The Indirect Coomb's test detects: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Antibodies in the serum

 

Explanation:
 

The Indirect Coombs test (also called indirect antiglobulin test) detects antibodies present in the patient's serum that may bind to donor erythrocytes. This test involves obtaining the recipient's serum, adding donor blood samples, and looking for antibody-antigen complexes. When anti-human immunoglobulins (Coombs reagent) are added to the solution, agglutination occurs if human antibodies have attached to the red blood cells, indicating a positive test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antibodies attached to the RBC surface: This describes what the Direct Coombs test detects. The Direct test examines antibodies already bound to the patient's own RBCs.

 

Option C. Antigens attached to the RBC surface: The test detects antibodies, not antigens. While antigens on RBCs are what the antibodies bind to, the test specifically identifies the antibodies.

 

Option D. Antigens in the serum: Antigens are typically cell-surface molecules, not free-floating in serum. The test specifically identifies antibodies in serum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Indirect Coombs test is a critical pretransfusion screening test that detects antibodies in a recipient's serum that could react with donor RBCs, helping prevent potentially fatal hemolytic transfusion reactions.

questions.text: The occurrence of hyperthyroidism following the administration of supplemental iodine to individuals with endemic iodine deficiency goiter is known as: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Jod-Basedow effect

 

The Jod-Basedow effect refers to hyperthyroidism that occurs when individuals with preexisting thyroid disease (particularly those with endemic iodine deficiency goiter) receive supplemental iodine. In patients with long-standing iodine deficiency, the thyroid glands develop autonomous nodules that produce excess thyroid hormone when suddenly exposed to iodine supplementation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wolff-Chaikoff Effect: This is the transient inhibition of thyroid hormone synthesis that occurs in response to high iodine intake. In normal glands, this effect is temporary (9-10 days) as the thyroid "escapes" from this inhibition. It causes hypothyroidism, not hyperthyroidism.

 

Option C. Pendred's syndrome: This is a genetic disorder characterized by congenital sensorineural hearing loss and goiter. It's not related to iodine administration causing hyperthyroidism.

 

Option D. De Quervain's thyroiditis: This is another name for subacute granulomatous thyroiditis, which is a painful inflammatory condition of the thyroid, typically following a viral infection. It's not directly related to iodine administration.

 

Educational Objective: The Jod-Basedow effect represents paradoxical hyperthyroidism following iodine administration in patients with preexisting iodine deficiency, as their thyroid glands have adapted to produce hormones even with minimal iodine availability.

questions.text: The diagnosis of a carcinoid tumor is done by urinary estimation of? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 5 HIAA

 

Explanation:

 

Carcinoid tumors are neuroendocrine tumors that secrete serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine). When metabolized, serotonin produces 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA), which is excreted in the urine. Neuroendocrine tumors like carcinoid are causes of secretory diarrhea, and specific diagnostic markers include elevated serum Chromogranin A (CgA) and urinary 5-HIAA.

 

 Other Options:

 

Option A. VMA (Vanillylmandelic Acid): VMA is a metabolite of catecholamines (epinephrine and norepinephrine). It is elevated in pheochromocytoma and neuroblastoma, not in carcinoid tumors.

 

Option B. Metanephrines: These are also metabolites of catecholamines and are elevated in pheochromocytoma. They are not associated with carcinoid tumors.

 

Option C. Catecholamines: These are hormones including epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine. They are elevated in conditions like pheochromocytoma and neuroblastoma, not in carcinoid tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carcinoid tumors are neuroendocrine tumors that secrete serotonin, which when metabolized produces 5-HIAA that can be measured in urine as a diagnostic marker. Chromogranin A (CgA) is another important tumor marker for carcinoid tumors.

choices.text: Low TSH levels
Low free T4 levels
Low serum T3 levels
Radioactive iodine Uptake (RAIU) at 24 hours below normal

questions.text: A middle-aged woman who presented with tremors, palpitations, weight loss, and menstrual irregularities is diagnosed with Graves' disease. Which of the following statements would be correct with respect to her thyroid function test? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Low TSH levels
 

Grave’s disease in an autoimmune disease characterized by production of antibodies against the TSH-Receptor which stimulates the gland resulting in release of thyroid hormones (T3, T4) producing symptoms of thyrotoxicosis. Elevated T3, 4 produce reduction in TSH via negative feedback.

 

Other options:

 

Option B, C: Elevated levels of T3, T4 are seen in Grave’s disease.

 

Option D: Due to stimulation of the gland, there is Homogenous uptake on RAIU scan.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Graves' disease, low TSH levels are a key diagnostic marker reflecting the increased production and release of thyroid hormones T3 and T4, which exert negative feedback on the pituitary gland to reduce TSH secretion.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Hyperthyroidism/Grave’s disease/Chap 384

questions.text: A 25-year-old software engineer presented with fatigue and lethargy. He worked for 12-14 hours a day, and his diet pattern consisted predominantly of fast food with very little veggies and greens. Labs: Hb - 9, MCV 106. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Folate deficiency

 

The patient presents with macrocytic anemia, indicated by an MCV of 106. Macrocytic anemia is often caused by deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folate. The patient's dietary habits, which include a diet predominantly of fast food with very little vegetables and greens, suggest a lack of dietary folate.

 

  • Vitamin B12 deficiency: Typically occurs in individuals who do not consume animal products (vegans). This deficiency is less likely in this patient due to the absence of such a dietary restriction.
  • Folate deficiency: Common in individuals with poor intake of vegetables and greens. This matches the patient's dietary pattern.
  • Iron deficiency: Results in microcytic anemia (MCV < 80), not macrocytic anemia.
  • Hemolytic anemia: Usually presents as normocytic anemia (MCV 80-100) with increased reticulocyte count and elevated LDH, which does not match the lab findings of this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. B12 deficiency: While B12 deficiency causes macrocytic anemia, it is more common in individuals who avoid animal products. The patient's history does not indicate a dietary restriction on animal products.

 

Option C. Iron deficiency: Iron deficiency causes microcytic anemia (low MCV), which is not consistent with the patient's lab findings of an MCV of 106.

 

Option D. Hemolytic anemia: Hemolytic anemia typically presents with normocytic anemia and increased reticulocyte count, not with the high MCV seen in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Folate deficiency should be considered in patients with macrocytic anemia and poor dietary intake of vegetables and greens. This deficiency can cause fatigue and lethargy and is confirmed by a high MCV and dietary history.

choices.text: Ipsilateral upper and lower halves of the face
Contralateral upper and lower halves of the face
Ipsilateral lower half of the face
Contralateral lower half of the face

questions.text: Bell's palsy involves: (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ipsilateral upper and lower halves of the face

 

Bell's palsy is an idiopathic lower motor neuron type of facial nerve palsy that results in paralysis of both the upper and lower halves of the face on the same side (ipsilateral) as the lesion. It is characterized by sudden onset facial muscle weakness or paralysis that affects one side of the face.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Contralateral upper and lower halves of the face: Would suggest a central (upper motor neuron) lesion.

 

Option C. Ipsilateral lower half of the face: Indicates a central lesion affecting the facial nerve pathway above the level of the facial nucleus.

 

Option D. Contralateral lower half of the face: Also indicates a central lesion affecting the corticobulbar tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bell's palsy involves ipsilateral paralysis of both the upper and lower halves of the face due to a lower motor neuron lesion of the facial nerve.

questions.text: A 60-year-old bedridden patient develops acute onset dyspnea and chest pain. A CT pulmonary angiography was done. Which screening test will be useful to determine the etiology of this patient's condition? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) D-dimer measurement

 

Explanation:

 

In a bedridden patient presenting with acute onset dyspnea and chest pain, one of the primary differential diagnoses is pulmonary embolism (PE). The patient has already undergone CT pulmonary angiography, which is a gold standard for diagnosing PE.

 

However, for initial screening, D-dimer measurement is very useful:

 

  • D-dimer: This test has a high negative predictive value and high sensitivity. It is a good screening test because if the D-dimer level is negative/ normal, it effectively rules out venous thromboembolism (VTE) such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and PE.
  • Elevated D-dimer levels indicate that further diagnostic imaging, such as CT pulmonary angiography or compression ultrasound, is needed to confirm the presence of VTE, given its poor specificity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MR Angiogram: This is an imaging modality that can be used for vascular imaging but is not typically used as a screening test for PE.

 

Option B. Echocardiography: This is useful for assessing heart function and diagnosing conditions like heart failure or valvular disease but is not a primary screening test for PE.

 

Option D. Coagulogram: This test assesses blood coagulation status but is not specifically used for screening for PE.

 

Educational Objectives

 

D-dimer measurement is an effective screening test for ruling out pulmonary embolism in patients presenting with symptoms suggestive of VTE.

questions.text: A patient was admitted to the ICU 48 hours after the fracture of the femur. The Cerebellum saturation of oxygen in the rebreathing unit was 100% but his SpO2 remained at 60%. The patient is in a state of confusion. Chest X ray showed lung fields to be clear. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fat embolism

 

After any long bone fracture, it is essential to consider fat embolism, particularly when the patient presents with confusion and neurological symptoms within the typical timeframe. Fat embolism syndrome (FES) usually occurs 1 to 3 days after the fracture, with symptoms including respiratory distress, petechial rash, and neurological changes.

 

To diagnose fat embolism syndrome, the GERD criteria are used, which include:

 

  1. Petechial Rash: Often seen in the conjunctiva, axilla, or skin folds.
  2. Neurological Symptoms: Confusion, altered consciousness, or focal neurological deficits.
  3. Respiratory Symptoms: Hypoxemia or dyspnea.
  4. Fat Globules in the Blood: Confirmed by laboratory tests.

 

Given that the symptoms are occurring around the 48-hour mark post-fracture and include neurological involvement, the diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome is appropriate. Pulmonary embolism is less likely in this case because it typically requires more extended immobilization, such as more than 72 hours, to develop.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary embolism: Would typically show hypoxemia but may also show signs on CXR and is less common in this context.

 

Option C. ARDS: Usually presents with diffuse infiltrates on CXR.

 

Option D. Occult pneumothorax: Would likely show abnormalities on CXR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fat embolism syndrome presents with hypoxemia, confusion, and often clear lung fields on CXR, following long bone fractures.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with headache and bitemporal hemianopia. Hormonal evaluation was normal. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gonadotroph adenoma

 

The presence of headache and bitemporal hemianopia suggests a pituitary adenoma with mass effect. Normal hormonal evaluation suggests a non-functioning adenoma. Gonadotroph adenomas are the most common non-functioning pituitary adenomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mammotroph adenoma: Would show elevated prolactin levels.

 

Option C. Corticotroph adenoma: Would present with features of Cushing's disease (elevated ACTH and cortisol).

 

Option D. Somatotroph adenoma: Would present with acromegaly or gigantism (elevated growth hormone).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gonadotroph adenomas are the most common non-functioning pituitary adenomas, presenting with mass effects like headache and visual field defects without hormonal hypersecretion.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs reduce mortality in a patient with heart failure? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metoprolol

 

Metoprolol, specifically the succinate formulation, is a beta-blocker that has been shown to reduce mortality in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). Beta-blockers like metoprolol, bisoprolol, and carvedilol improve survival, reduce hospitalizations, and improve symptoms in heart failure patients.

 

Note - Drugs that reduce mortality in patients with heart failure, in a recommended order of use:

 

  1. First Line Drug: ACE inhibitors helps to relax blood vessels and improve blood flow, thereby decreasing the heart's workload.
  2. Second Line Drug: Beta blockers worked by slowing the heart rate and reducing blood pressure, which decreases the heart's demand for oxygen.
  3. Third Line Drug: Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists, such as spironolactone helps to remove excess sodium and water from the body, relieving pressure on the heart while preserving potassium levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Furosemide: A loop diuretic that provides symptomatic relief by reducing fluid overload but does not reduce mortality in heart failure patients.

 

Option C. Prazosin: An alpha-blocker used for hypertension but not shown to reduce mortality in heart failure.

 

Option D. Torsemide: Another loop diuretic similar to furosemide, effective for symptomatic relief but not for reducing mortality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta-blockers, such as metoprolol succinate, are essential in reducing mortality in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction

 

Note –

 

Drugs That Reduce Mortality in Heart Failure

 

  1. ARNIs (Angiotensin Receptor-Neprilysin Inhibitors):
    • Examples: Sacubitril/Valsartan
    • Currently the first-line treatment, considered superior to ACE inhibitors and ARBs when available.
       
  2. ACE Inhibitors (Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme inhibitors) and ARBs (Angiotensin II Receptor Blockers):
    • Considered equally effective in efficacy; used when ARNIs are not available.
       
  3. Beta Blockers:
    • Specific agents highlighted: Metoprolol, Bisoprolol, and Carvedilol.
       
  4. MRS (Mineralocorticoid Receptor Antagonists):
    • Examples: Spironolactone and Eplerenone.
       
  5. SGLT2 Inhibitors (Sodium-Glucose Cotransporter 2 inhibitors):
    • Emerging class of drugs also showing benefits in heart failure management.
       
  6. Hydralazine and Isosorbide Dinitrate (HISDN):
    • Noted specifically for proven benefits in African American patients with heart failure.

 

Drugs with No Impact on Mortality

 

  1. Diuretics:
    • Including loop and thiazide diuretics, noted to not improve survival but are used primarily for symptom management and fluid regulation.
       
  2. Calcium Channel Blockers and Nitrates:
    • Mentioned as not improving survival in heart failure, particularly in patients with reduced ejection fraction.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with brown-colored urine, flank pain, and fatigue for the last 3 days. He has 2+ proteinuria with >20 red cells/HPF and dysmorphic red blood cells. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation of a 10-year-old child with brown-colored urine, flank pain, fatigue, significant proteinuria, and dysmorphic red blood cells suggests a diagnosis of glomerulonephritis. Among the given options, the most likely diagnosis is Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). Key points supporting this diagnosis include:

 

  • Brown-colored urine (tea or cola colored): Indicates hematuria.
  • Flank pain and fatigue: Common symptoms associated with glomerulonephritis.
  • Proteinuria and dysmorphic red blood cells: Indicate glomerular origin of hematuria, typical in glomerulonephritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urinary tract infection: Usually presents with isomorphic red blood cells rather than dysmorphic red blood cells and would typically be associated with symptoms of urinary frequency, urgency, and dysuria.

 

Option C. Bladder calculi: Can cause hematuria but typically produces isomorphic red blood cells, not dysmorphic ones.

 

Option D. Minimal change disease: Usually presents with nephrotic syndrome, characterized by heavy proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, edema, and frothy urine, rather than hematuria and dysmorphic red blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is a common cause of glomerulonephritis in children, presenting with hematuria, proteinuria, and dysmorphic red blood cells following a streptococcal infection.

questions.text: A person with history of RTA admitted in hospital. He is able to understand what his friend is talking but he is unable to speak. Which part of the brain is most likely to be injured in this case? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Broca's area

 

Explanation

 

In the scenario described, the patient is able to understand spoken language but is unable to speak, indicating that comprehension is intact while fluency is impaired. This condition is characteristic of Broca's aphasia, which results from damage to Broca's area in the frontal lobe of the brain.

 

Broca's area is responsible for speech production and language processing. Damage to this area leads to non-fluent aphasia, where the patient struggles to form words and sentences despite understanding spoken language. This condition is often seen in individuals who have experienced a stroke or traumatic brain injury.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Wernicke's area: Damage to Wernicke's area results in Wernicke's aphasia, characterized by fluent but nonsensical speech and impaired comprehension. The patient would not understand spoken language.

 

Option C. Angular gyrus: Damage to the angular gyrus typically results in Gerstmann syndrome, characterized by a tetrad of symptoms: acalculia (difficulty with calculations), agraphia (difficulty writing), right-left confusion, and finger agnosia.

 

Option D. Arcuate fasciculus: Damage to the arcuate fasciculus causes conduction aphasia, where the patient has intact comprehension and fluency but cannot repeat words or phrases.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Broca's area damage results in Broca's aphasia, characterized by impaired speech production with intact comprehension.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man after drinking too much alcohol developed chest pain. X-ray showed pneumomediastinum. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Esophageal perforation

 

Esophageal perforation is a serious condition that can occur spontaneously, often after episodes of severe vomiting or retching, commonly associated with excessive alcohol consumption. This condition can lead to the presence of air in the mediastinum (pneumomediastinum), which can be detected on an X-ray. The classic clinical presentation includes chest pain, pneumomediastinum, and subcutaneous emphysema. When the perforation occurs spontaneously, it is known as Boerhaave syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mallory Weiss syndrome: This condition involves a partial tear at the gastroesophageal junction, usually following severe vomiting. It typically presents with hematemesis (vomiting blood) but does not cause pneumomediastinum.

 

Option C. Pulsion diverticulum: This type of diverticulum is an outpouching of the esophageal wall due to increased intraluminal pressure. While it can cause dysphagia and regurgitation, it does not typically present with pneumomediastinum.

 

Option D. Acute Pericarditis: Acute pericarditis is inflammation of the pericardium and typically presents with sharp chest pain that worsens with deep breathing or lying down. It does not cause pneumomediastinum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Esophageal perforation, often associated with severe vomiting and alcohol consumption, can present with chest pain, pneumomediastinum, and subcutaneous emphysema, and is a medical emergency.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with a history of recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, particularly involving the skin and respiratory tract. The patient's parents report that he has had multiple abscesses and lymphadenitis. Dihydro-rhodamine test results show an abnormal pattern. What is the primary suspicion based on these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic Granulomatous Disease

 

Explanation

 

Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) is a genetic disorder that affects the body's ability to produce reactive oxygen species (ROS) necessary to kill certain bacteria and fungi. This condition is most commonly inherited in an X-linked recessive manner due to a defect in the CYBB gene, which encodes a component of the NADPH oxidase enzyme complex.

 

Patients with CGD typically present with recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, particularly affecting the skin, lungs, and lymph nodes. The dihydro-rhodamine (DHR) test, which measures the oxidative burst of neutrophils, is used to diagnose CGD. An abnormal DHR test indicates a defect in the NADPH oxidase enzyme, confirming the diagnosis of CGD.

 

Investigation – NBT and DHR 123 test (flow cytometry)

 

TOC – Allogenic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation; IFN gamma

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID): SCID is characterized by a severe defect in both T- and B-lymphocyte systems. It presents very early in life with severe immunodeficiency and is often due to adenosine deaminase deficiency.

 

Option C. Sialyl Lewis X defect: This results in leukocyte adhesion defect type 2 (LAD-2), which involves issues with leukocyte migration due to defective carbohydrate metabolism affecting leukocyte rolling.

 

Option D. Leukocyte Adhesion Defect (LAD): LAD type 1 involves a defect in the CD18 gene affecting leukocyte adhesion and migration, leading to recurrent infections without pus formation and poor wound healing. LAD type 2 involves a defect in the Sialyl Lewis X structure.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Chronic Granulomatous Disease is diagnosed with the DHR test, which reveals defects in the oxidative burst of neutrophils due to NADPH oxidase deficiency.

questions.text: A patient with dermatitis herpetiformis presented with chronic diarrhea. What is the likely cause of diarrhea? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Celiac disease

 

Dermatitis herpetiformis is a chronic skin condition characterized by intensely itchy and blistering skin lesions. It is strongly associated with celiac disease, an autoimmune disorder triggered by the ingestion of gluten. In celiac disease, exposure to gluten leads to an immune response that damages the lining of the small intestine, resulting in malabsorption and chronic diarrhea.

 

Key points:

 

  • Dermatitis herpetiformis: This condition involves IgA deposits in the tips of the dermal papillae, as seen on skin biopsy. It is a specific marker for celiac disease.
  • Celiac disease: Caused by gluten hypersensitivity, it leads to intestinal inflammation, villous atrophy, and malabsorption, which in turn causes chronic diarrhea.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ulcerative colitis: This is an inflammatory bowel disease affecting the colon and rectum, leading to symptoms like diarrhea and abdominal pain. It is not associated with dermatitis herpetiformis.

 

Option B. Whipple’s disease: This rare bacterial infection affects multiple systems, including the intestines, causing malabsorption and diarrhea. It does not have a connection with dermatitis herpetiformis.

 

Option D. Crohn’s disease: Another type of inflammatory bowel disease that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract, causing chronic diarrhea and abdominal pain. It is not related to dermatitis herpetiformis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dermatitis herpetiformis is a skin manifestation of celiac disease, and the presence of chronic diarrhea in such a patient is indicative of celiac disease due to gluten hypersensitivity.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with features of massive splenomegaly. On examination, his TLC was more than 85,000/mm³ with immature cells and a shift to the left with the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome. The mutation associated with the Philadelphia chromosome is? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Translocation

 

Explanation

 

Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) is characterized by the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome, which results from a balanced reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22. Specifically, the ABL1 gene on chromosome 9 is translocated to the BCR gene on chromosome 22, resulting in the BCR-ABL fusion gene. This fusion gene encodes a protein with constitutively active tyrosine kinase activity, which leads to uncontrolled cell proliferation.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Inversion: This involves a segment of a chromosome being reversed end to end. It is not associated with the formation of the Philadelphia chromosome.

 

Option C. Deletion: This refers to the loss of a chromosome segment. It is not related to the Philadelphia chromosome.

 

Option D. Insertion: This involves the addition of one or more nucleotide base pairs into a DNA sequence. It is not the mechanism behind the Philadelphia chromosome.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

The Philadelphia chromosome is the result of a balanced reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22, forming the BCR-ABL fusion gene, which is a hallmark of Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML).

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic presented with abdominal pain. His amylase and lipase levels were elevated. Which of the following will be seen? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Enzymatic fat necrosis

 

The patient, a chronic alcoholic, presents with abdominal pain and elevated levels of amylase and lipase, which are indicative of pancreatitis. In cases of both acute and chronic pancreatitis, the typical pathological finding is enzymatic fat necrosis. This occurs when pancreatic enzymes, particularly lipase, escape into the surrounding tissues, leading to fat digestion and necrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Coagulative necrosis: This type of necrosis is typically associated with ischemic injury, such as myocardial infarction, and is characterized by the preservation of cellular outlines.

 

Option C. Caseous necrosis: This type of necrosis is characteristic of tuberculosis infections and some fungal infections. It presents with a cheese-like appearance and is not associated with pancreatitis.

 

Option D. Fibrinoid necrosis:  This type of necrosis is usually seen in immune reactions involving blood vessels, such as in vasculitis or severe hypertension, where immune complexes and fibrin are deposited in vessel walls.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pancreatitis, especially in chronic alcoholics, the characteristic pathological finding is enzymatic fat necrosis, resulting from the action of pancreatic enzymes on the surrounding fatty tissues.

questions.text: Which of the following is suggestive of pseudomembranous colitis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A)

 

Option 'A' is the correct answer because it shows the characteristic yellowish pseudomembrane along with ulcers, which are key indicators of pseudomembranous colitis. This condition is typically caused by an overgrowth of Clostridium difficile bacteria, often following antibiotic use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: This image is suggestive of feline esophagitis, often associated with eosinophilic esophagitis, due to the presence of inflammation and possibly eosinophilic infiltrates in the esophagus.

 

Option C: This image depicts diverticulosis, characterized by the presence of small pouches (diverticula) protruding from the colon wall.

 

Option D: This image is suggestive of cancer or malignancy due to the presence of a distinct mass.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pseudomembranous colitis is characterized by the presence of yellowish pseudomembranes and ulcers in the colon, often caused by Clostridium difficile overgrowth.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient who was being treated for hypertriglyceridemia developed flushing, gout, hyperglycemia, and raised liver enzymes. Which drug is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nicotinamide

 

Nicotinamide, also known as niacin, is known to cause a range of side effects that match the patient's symptoms. These include:

 

  • Flushing: Niacin can cause prostaglandin-mediated flushing, leading to a sensation of warmth and redness in the skin.
  • Gout: Niacin can increase uric acid levels, potentially triggering or worsening gout in susceptible individuals.
  • Hyperglycemia: Niacin can impair glucose tolerance and lead to elevated blood sugar levels, especially in people with diabetes or prediabetes.
  • Raised liver enzymes: Niacin can cause liver damage in some cases, resulting in elevated liver enzymes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atorvastatin: Atorvastatin, a statin drug, is primarily used to lower cholesterol levels.It is not typically associated with flushing, gout, or hyperglycemia.

 

Option B. Fenofibrate: Fenofibrate is another lipid-lowering medication that can sometimes cause mild elevations in liver enzymes. However, it is not known to cause flushing, gout, or hyperglycemia.

 

Option D. Ezetimibe: Ezetimibe works by inhibiting cholesterol absorption in the intestine. It is generally well-tolerated and has a low risk of side effects. It is not associated with any of the patient's symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Niacin (nicotinamide) therapy can be associated with side effects like flushing, gout, hyperglycemia, and elevated liver enzymes. Clinicians should be aware of these potential adverse effects when prescribing niacin and monitor patients accordingly

questions.text: Which of the following growth hormone analogs is not used for the treatment of growth hormone deficiency, but is used in the treatment of HIV-associated lipodystrophy? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tesamorelin

 

Tesamorelin is a growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH) analog. It stimulates the pituitary gland to release growth hormone. While it can be used to treat growth hormone deficiency, it is specifically approved for the treatment of HIV-associated lipodystrophy. This condition causes abnormal fat distribution in people with HIV. Tesamorelin helps to reduce excess abdominal fat in these patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sermorelin: This is another GHRH analog used to diagnose growth hormone deficiency. It's not approved for treating HIV-associated lipodystrophy.

 

Option C. Somatropin: This is a synthetic form of human growth hormone used to treat growth hormone deficiency in children and adults. It's not indicated for HIV-associated lipodystrophy.

 

Option D. Pegvisomant: This is a growth hormone receptor antagonist. It blocks the effects of growth hormone and is used to treat acromegaly, a condition caused by excess growth hormone. It's not used for HIV-associated lipodystrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tesamorelin is the only growth hormone analog specifically approved for the treatment of HIV-associated lipodystrophy.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female in late pregnancy presents with seizures and high blood pressure. She is diagnosed with eclampsia and started on magnesium sulfate therapy. As part of her management, certain parameters require close monitoring to prevent magnesium toxicity. Which of the following parameters does NOT require routine checking during magnesium sulfate therapy in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serum magnesium levels

 

While monitoring serum magnesium levels can be helpful in certain situations, it is not routinely required in all patients receiving magnesium sulfate therapy for eclampsia. Routine clinical assessments, including monitoring deep tendon reflexes, urine output, and respiratory rate, are generally sufficient to detect signs of magnesium toxicity.

 

Serum magnesium levels may be indicated in specific cases, such as when there is a suspicion of toxicity (e.g., loss of deep tendon reflexes, respiratory depression), or if the patient has pre-existing renal impairment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Urine output: Magnesium is primarily excreted by the kidneys. Monitoring urine output helps ensure adequate renal function and magnesium clearance, preventing toxicity.

 

Option B. Deep tendon reflexes: Magnesium can depress the central nervous system. Diminished or absent deep tendon reflexes are an early sign of magnesium toxicity.

 

Option D. Respiratory rate: Magnesium can also cause respiratory depression. Monitoring respiratory rate helps identify this serious complication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients receiving magnesium sulfate for eclampsia, routine monitoring of deep tendon reflexes, urine output, and respiratory rate is essential. Serum magnesium levels are not routinely checked unless there are specific indications

questions.text: A 30-year-old drug addict presents to the emergency department with signs of unknown drug poisoning. The patient exhibits dilated pupils, sweating, tachycardia, and tremors. On examination, the blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg, and the heart rate is 120 beats per minute. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cocaine intoxication

 

The patient's symptoms of dilated pupils (mydriasis), sweating, tachycardia, tremors, hypertension, and elevated heart rate are classic signs of cocaine intoxication. Cocaine is a stimulant that activates the sympathetic nervous system, leading to these physiological responses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Morphine poisoning: Morphine, an opioid, typically causes pinpoint pupils (miosis), not dilated pupils. It also leads to respiratory depression, decreased blood pressure, and decreased heart rate, which are not present in this case.

 

Option C. Cannabis poisoning: While cannabis can cause mild euphoria and tachycardia, it does not typically lead to the severe hypertension, tremors, and sweating observed in this patient.

 

Option D. Alcohol intoxication: Alcohol intoxication usually presents with slurred speech, impaired coordination, and decreased blood pressure. It can also lead to hypoglycemia. These symptoms are not consistent with the patient's presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cocaine intoxication is characterized by dilated pupils, sweating, tachycardia, tremors, and hypertension.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the treatment of Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) has a direct spasmolytic action on gastrointestinal (GI) smooth muscle?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mebeverine

 

Mebeverine is a musculotropic antispasmodic drug. It directly targets the smooth muscle of the gastrointestinal tract, causing relaxation and relieving spasms. This makes it effective in managing the abdominal pain and discomfort associated with IBS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dicyclomine: While dicyclomine can help with IBS symptoms, it works indirectly by blocking acetylcholine receptors, thus reducing muscle contractions. It's an anticholinergic drug, not a direct spasmolytic.

 

Option B. Scopolamine: Similar to dicyclomine, scopolamine is an anticholinergic drug that works indirectly to reduce smooth muscle contractions. It's not a direct spasmolytic.

 

Option D. Racecadotril: Racecadotril is an antidiarrheal medication. It works by inhibiting enkephalinase, an enzyme that breaks down enkephalins, which regulate intestinal fluid secretion. It doesn't have a direct spasmolytic action.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mebeverine is a direct spasmolytic drug used in the treatment of IBS, acting directly on the GI smooth muscle to relieve spasms and pain.

questions.text: A patient had a blunt injury to the abdomen after an RTA and underwent ileal resection. He recovered well post-surgery but months later presents with fatigue and exercise intolerance. Which of the following will not be seen? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Microcytic hypochromic anemia

 

Ileal resection can lead to vitamin B12 deficiency due to impaired absorption. Vitamin B12 deficiency causes megaloblastic anemia, characterized by large, immature red blood cells (macrocytosis). Microcytic hypochromic anemia, on the other hand, is characterized by small, pale red blood cells and is typically associated with iron deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytonuclear dyssynchrony: This refers to the asynchronous maturation of the nucleus and cytoplasm in red blood cells, a characteristic feature of megaloblastic anemia seen in B12 deficiency.

 

Option C. Romberg's sign positive: This indicates impaired proprioception, which can be a manifestation of subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, a neurological complication of B12 deficiency

 

Option D. Subacute combined degeneration: This is a demyelinating disease of the spinal cord that can occur due to B12 deficiency, leading to neurological symptoms like impaired proprioception and gait disturbances

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ileal resection can lead to vitamin B12 deficiency, which manifests as megaloblastic anemia (macrocytic) and neurological symptoms like subacute combined degeneration.

choices.text: Atrophy of the right lower limb
Loss of proprioception in the left leg
Ankle clonus in the right foot

questions.text: A 40-year-old man had a RTA and was admitted to a hospital. After a few days, he had an exaggerated right-sided extensor plantar reflex and knee jerk. What other finding would be seen? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ankle clonus in the right foot

 

The presentation suggests Brown-Sequard syndrome, which is a hemisection of the spinal cord. In this condition, there's:

 

  • Ipsilateral (same side) findings:
    • Loss of proprioception and fine touch due to damage to the posterior column.
    • Upper motor neuron signs (e.g., spasticity, exaggerated reflexes, ankle clonus) due to damage to the corticospinal tract.
  • Contralateral (opposite side) findings:
    • Loss of pain and temperature sensation due to damage to the spinothalamic tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atrophy of the right lower limb: Atrophy is a feature of lower motor neuron lesions, not upper motor neuron lesions seen in Brown-Sequard syndrome.

 

Option B. Loss of proprioception in the left leg: Loss of proprioception would be on the same side (right leg) as the lesion in Brown-Sequard syndrome.

 

Option D. Fasciculations in the right foot: Fasciculations are also a sign of lower motor neuron lesions and are not expected in Brown-Sequard syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brown-Sequard syndrome presents with ipsilateral loss of proprioception and upper motor neuron signs, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation.
